newsitem.title: FRANCE: Kleinwort could upgrade Saint Louis.
newsitem.headline: Kleinwort could upgrade Saint Louis.

text.p: Dresdner Kleinwort Benson analyst Charles Manso said he was reviewing his recommendation of Saint Louis and could possibly upgrade his "hold" rating after the food group bought a 15 percent stake in Ebro Agricolas.
"This is the second bit of good news in two days. We have to factor that in. I think today's deal is slightly earnings enhancing," Manso said.
On Monday, Saint Louis said it was closing its Bresles sugar plant as part of a rationalisation of its production structure.
On Tuesday morning it said its Generale Sucriere holding had bought the Ebro stake from Banco Santander.
Saint Louis already has a 20.35 percent stake in Sociedad General de Azucarera de Espana (Azucarera), Spain's second largest sugar group.
Ebro and Azucarera are planning to merge their operations.
Saint Louis chairman Daniel Melin said in December that he aimed for a 20 to 25 percent stake in the merged company.
Kleinwort's Manso said he would not be surprised if Saint Louis were to take a majority in the future.
"The new management has been in place for 18 months now and they are doing the right things," Manso said.
In November, Saint Louis sold its Royal Champignon mushroom unit to Champi-Jandou and it has made provisions for restructuring at its 40 percent paper unit Arjo Wiggins Appleton .
Melin, a former head of construction group Spie Batignolles, was named chairman and chief executive at Saint Louis in May 1995 after Bernard Dumon had died in a plane crash in January.
Bank Worms et Cie has 27.8 percent in Saint Louis and Italy's IFIL Spa, a finance company controlled by the Agnelli family, has a 25.9 percent stake.
At 1015 GMT, Saint Louis shares were up 0.83 percent at 1,338 francs.
